controls.title: Ensure rsyslog logging is configured
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.conf
\f2 \cf2  and 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
\f2 \cf2  files specifies rules for logging\
and which files are to be used to log certain classes of messages.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 A great deal of important security-related information is sent via 
\f0 \cf4 rsyslog
\f2 \cf2  (e.g.,\
successful and failed su attempts, failed login attempts, root login attempts, etc.).\

\f1\b
controls.audit_command:
\

\f2\b0 Review the contents of 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.conf
\f2 \cf2  and 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
\f2 \cf2  files to\
ensure appropriate logging is set. In addition, run the following command and verify that\
the log files are logging information as expected:\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 # ls -l /var/log/\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.remediation:
\

\f2\b0 Edit the following lines in the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.conf
\f2 \cf2  and 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf
\f2 \cf2  files\
as appropriate for your environment.\

\f1\b Note:
\f2\b0  The below configuration is shown for example purposes only. Due care should be\
given to how the organization wishes to store log data.\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 *.emerg :omusrmsg:*\
auth,authpriv.* /var/log/secure\

mail.info -/var/log/mail.info\
mail.warning -/var/log/mail.warn\
mail.err /var/log/mail.err\
cron.* /var/log/cron\
*.=warning;*.=err -/var/log/warn\
*.crit /var/log/warn\
*.*;mail.none;news.none -/var/log/messages\
local0,local1.* -/var/log/localmessages\
local2,local3.* -/var/log/localmessages\
local4,local5.* -/var/log/localmessages\
local6,local7.* -/var/log/localme

controls.title: Ensure logrotate is configured
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The system includes the capability of rotating log files regularly to avoid filling up the\
system with logs or making the logs unmanageably large. The file\

\f0 \cf4 /etc/logrotate.d/syslog
\f2 \cf2  is the configuration file used to rotate log files created by\

\f0 \cf4 syslog
\f2 \cf2  or 
\f0 \cf4 rsyslog
\f2 \cf2 .\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 By keeping the log files smaller and more manageable, a system administrator can\
easily archive these files to another system and spend less time looking through\
inordinately large log files.\

\f1\b
controls.audit_command:
\

\f2\b0 Review 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/logrotate.conf
\f2 \cf2  and 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/logrotate.d/*
\f2 \cf2  and verify logs are rotated\
according to site policy.\

\f1\b
controls.remediation:
\

\f2\b0 Edit 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/logrotate.conf
\f2 \cf2  and 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/logrotate.d/*
\f2 \cf2  to ensure logs are rotated\
according to site policy.\

controls.title: Ensure access to all logfiles has been configured\
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 Log files contain information from many services on the the local system, or in the event\
of a centralized log server, others systems logs as well.\
In general log files are found in 
\f0 \cf4 /var/log/

store logs elsewhere. Should your application store logs in another, ensure to run the\
same test on that location.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\

\f2\b0 It is important that log files have the correct permissions to ensure that sensitive data is\
protected and that only the appropriate users / groups have access to them.
